quiz.title: Midterm Review: Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: Scientific Method, Measurement, Motion, Force & Energy
quiz.subject: Science

questions.question: In the scientific method, what is the step that comes immediately after making an observation and asking a question?
questions.explanation: The standard sequence is: 1. Observation/Question, 2. Hypothesis, 3. Experiment, 4. Analysis, 5. Conclusion.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a control group in an experiment?
options: To provide a baseline for comparison
To ensure the experiment is complex
To test multiple variables at once
questions.explanation: A control group is not exposed to the independent variable and is used as a benchmark to compare against the experimental group.

questions.question: Which of the following is the base unit for mass in the International System of Units (SI)?
questions.explanation: The kilogram (kg) is the SI base unit for mass. The gram is a derived unit (1/1000 of a kg).

questions.question: A student measures the length of a pencil three times: 18.2 cm, 18.1 cm, and 18.2 cm. The actual length is 18.0 cm. The measurements are:
questions.explanation: Precise: The measurements are close to each other (18.1, 18.2, 18.2). Not Accurate: They are not close to the true value of 18.0 cm.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the speed of an object?
options: The distance traveled per unit of time
The change in velocity over time
The total length of the path traveled
The rate of change of displacement
questions.explanation: Speed is a scalar quantity defined as distance divided by time (e.g., m/s or km/h).

questions.question: A car travels 150 kilometers in 2 hours. What is its average speed?
questions.explanation: Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time = 150 km / 2 h = 75 km/h.

questions.question: Velocity is different from speed because velocity includes:
questions.explanation: Velocity is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude (speed) and direction. Speed is a scalar with only magnitude.

questions.question: If an object is moving at a constant velocity, what can be said about its acceleration?
options: It is constant but not zero
questions.explanation: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. If velocity is constant (no change in speed or direction), then acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A force is best defined as:
options: A push or a pull on an object
The energy an object has due to its motion
The amount of matter in an object
The speed and direction of an object
questions.explanation: A force is any interaction that, when unopposed, will change the motion of an object. It is a push or a pull.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation: The Newton (N) is the SI unit of force. 1 N is defined as the force needed to accelerate 1 kg of mass at 1 m/s².

questions.question: According to Newton's First Law of Motion, an object at rest will remain at rest, and an object in motion will remain in motion, unless acted upon by a(n):
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law (the Law of Inertia) states that an object will maintain its state of motion unless an unbalanced net force acts upon it.

questions.question: The tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion is called:
questions.explanation: Inertia is the property of matter that causes it to resist any change in its motion. It is directly related to an object's mass.

questions.question: The force that attracts any two objects with mass is called:
questions.explanation: Gravity is a universal force of attraction between all objects that have mass.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best example of kinetic energy?
options: A ball rolling across the floor
A book sitting on a high shelf
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is the energy of motion. A rolling ball is clearly in motion.

questions.question: A rock sitting at the edge of a cliff has energy due to its position. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is stored energy due to an object's position in a gravitational field (its height).

questions.question: The Law of Conservation of Energy states that energy cannot be:
options: Transformed from one type to another
questions.explanation: The total energy in an isolated system remains constant. Energy can be transformed from one form to another (e.g., potential to kinetic) but the total amount is conserved.

questions.question: What type of energy is stored in a compressed spring?
questions.explanation: Elastic potential energy is the energy stored in elastic materials as a result of their stretching or compressing.

questions.question: Work, in physics, is done when a force causes an object to:
options: Move in the direction of the force
questions.explanation: Work is defined as force applied to an object multiplied by the distance the object moves in the direction of the force (W = F × d).

questions.question: Power is defined as the rate at which:
questions.explanation: Power is the amount of work done per unit of time (P = Work / Time). Its SI unit is the Watt (W).

questions.question: Which of the following is a unit of energy?
questions.explanation: The Joule (J) is the SI unit of energy and work. A Newton-meter (N·m) is also equal to one Joule.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of the fundamental concepts.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! Review a few specific areas to solidify your understanding.
scoreMessages.50: You know the basics. Focus your review on the definitions and core principles.
scoreMessages.0: Spend some time reviewing the core concepts of the scientific method, motion, forces, and energy.
